snippet: For decades, rumors have persisted that some of the best female athletes have in fact been men. As a result women have been subjected to tests, requiring certificates of femininity before they can compete in national or international events. But t...
lead_paragraph: For decades, rumors have persisted that some of the best female athletes have in fact been men. As a result women have been subjected to tests, requiring certificates of femininity before they can compete in national or international events. But the very idea of certifying femaleness raises a thorny question: Who is a man and who is a woman? For all its dazzling discoveries about the genes that guide a human embryo along its path to maleness or femaleness, science, it appears, cannot provide a simple answer.

headline.main: Who Is Female? Science Can't Say

lead_paragraph: Among the most crucial puzzles of modern medical science is that of atherosclerosis. This is the disease process in which human arteries become clogged and weakened by patchy deposits of fatty material. It is the underlying cause of most heart disease and ranks as the foremost killer of civilized man.

snippet: IS it possible for an adult of one of the higher animals to change its sex completely, male becoming female or female becoming male? It is not only possible; it has been done in three recently recorded instances, and probably in many that have not...
lead_paragraph: IS it possible for an adult of one of the higher animals to change its sex completely, male becoming female or female becoming male? It is not only possible; it has been done in three recently recorded instances, and probably in many that have not been observed, according to Dr. Oscar Riddle of the Station for Experimental Evolution conducted at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., by the Department of Genetics of the Carnegie Institution.

snippet: To the Editor:    When I was a high school student years ago, my biology teacher would always seat the boys up front and the girls in the back.     The teacher would call on a girl only if no boy raised his hand. All of the girls understood the me...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When I was a high school student years ago, my biology teacher would always seat the boys up front and the girls in the back. The teacher would call on a girl only if no boy raised his hand. All of the girls understood the message about our worthlessness in science, and I doubt that any of us pursued it in college or as a career.

snippet: The naked mole rats of east African deserts live like ants or bees; in a mole rat colony, one big female does all the breeding and most of the animals never even try to reproduce. For the most part, however, THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF MAMMALS is co...
lead_paragraph: The naked mole rats of east African deserts live like ants or bees; in a mole rat colony, one big female does all the breeding and most of the animals never even try to reproduce. For the most part, however, THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF MAMMALS is concerned with furrier creatures who appear in this collection of reporting from The Times's Tuesday science section: it explores the hearing of manatees (why can't they learn to avoid boats?), the return of the timber wolf, the probable evolution of the pronghorn antelope's amazing speed. Another volume in the series, THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF ARCHAEOLOGY, examines such recent discoveries as the oldest human footprints, the Stone Age outfit of the Tyrolean Iceman and the prehistoric graves in Kazakhstan whose female occupants have characteristics remarkably like those attributed to Amazons by the ancient Greeks. Both volumes are edited by Nicholas Wade, a reporter and former editor of Science Times, and published by the Lyons Press, $25 each.

snippet: Work is being done to improve the hiring of women at technology companies, but the overall numbers remain abysmal....
lead_paragraph: Work is being done to improve the hiring of women at technology companies, but the overall numbers remain abysmal.
abstract: Some 18 percent of computer science graduates were women in 2010, but at many prominent tech firms, where coding is king, the percentage of female programmers is in the single digits; those familiar with the field's hiring process attribute the lack of women to the recruiting process itself, with many firms relying on male interviewers who reinforce the profession's geeky, high-testosterone stereotype and give women the impression of a closed and unwelcoming culture.

headline.seo: Women’s Pipeline to Programming Jobs Has Many Leaks

snippet: Men still greatly outnumber women in computer science departments. But with the appointment of MARGARET H. WRIGHT, left, as chairwoman of New York University's computer science department effective in January, N.Y.U. will join Columbia as one of a...
lead_paragraph: Men still greatly outnumber women in computer science departments. But with the appointment of MARGARET H. WRIGHT, left, as chairwoman of New York University's computer science department effective in January, N.Y.U. will join Columbia as one of a handful of universities with female computer science chiefs. KATHLEEN McKEOWN became chairwoman at Columbia in 1997. Dr. Wright, a member of the National Academy of Engineering, received her bachelor's degree and Ph.D. from Stanford University and worked at Stanford until 1988, and then at Bell Laboratories. A former president of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, she is on the National Science Foundation's blue ribbon panel on cyberinfrastructure. Dr. Wright and Dr. McKeown have already talked about collaborating on events to help women advance in the computer sciences.
abstract: Margaret H Wright is named chairman of New York University's computer science department; photo (S)

snippet: Watching a male sweat bee mate with a female sweat bee, Penelope Kukuk, a Cornell University entomologist noticed that once they had mated the female seemed to lose her appeal to male bees, including the one with which she had just mated. The rese...
lead_paragraph: Watching a male sweat bee mate with a female sweat bee, Penelope Kukuk, a Cornell University entomologist noticed that once they had mated the female seemed to lose her appeal to male bees, including the one with which she had just mated. The researcher wondered why. She knew it had been suspected that male sweat bees could recognize and ''remember'' the odors of their female mates, and thereby avoid them. But she also realized that the males would have had to learn an incredible number of odors to perform such behavior, a feat of memory that was beyond insects that were no bigger than small houseflies.

headline.main: Antiaphrodisiac for Bees
